`vb.customize ["setextradata", :id, "VBoxInternal2/SharedFoldersEnableSymlinksCreate/vagrant", "1"]`

its mounted with a virtualbox filesystem that punches through to your host
what I suggest, at least to try it out is, copy the files in question such that they are within the local vagrant filesystem
at that point, you would be completely isolated from windows issues
if that works, then one thing we might be able to do is get clever with make directives
for instance, “mkdir /tmp/sdk; cd /tmp/sdk; cp -R $GOPATH/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/sdk/node"
then try building it there
as an aside, note that I have a PR outstanding (1948) that moves the sdk makefile down into sdk/node, so this will get even easier to do shortly
<https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/pull/1948/commits/08a4308afa5fdec433c6d30fd5ce36c8f54c2e78>

Hi, do we need to configure iptables for accessing docker container service from vagrant host ? If yes, could you please help on steps and related commands ?

<@U1F3CQ2HX> If you are running container using docker-compose. Here is a sample to setup port forwarding.
```membersrvc0:
  extends:
    file: compose-defaults.yml
    service: membersrvc
  ports:
    - 7054:7054
  volumes:
    - /volume/membersrvc:/var/hyperledger

vp0:
  extends:
    file: docker-compose-4-consensus-base.yml
    service: vpBatch
  environment:
    - CORE_PEER_ID=vp0
    - CORE_SECURITY_ENROLLID=test_vp0
    - CORE_SECURITY_ENROLLSECRET=MwYpmSRjupbT
    - CORE_PEER_PROFILE_ENABLED=true
  links:
    - membersrvc0
  ports:
    - 7050:7050
    - 7051:7051
  volumes:
    - /volume/vp0:/var/hyperledger```
Note this also includes volumes so that data can be reused.

If the container is already running. Then use iptables as you suggested. 
```iptables -t nat -A DOCKER -p tcp --dport 7050 -j DNAT --to-destination 172.17.0.3:7050```

Hi..In nodesk, when confidentiality is turned on, the paylaod is encrypted using the tx key... Is it encrypting using peers public key?
Hi, payload is encrypted using ECIES (hybrid encryption)  and ultimately using a chain-specific public key
peers have access to the chain-specific private (decryption) key
tx key is the emphemeral key used in this case (wrapped with pkchain)

text: <@U1BC5A0F9>  So if a client wants to decrypt the payload on his end how he can get access to the (chain specific) private key? Is there any way in sdk to get that through function call?

Well, the client stores the symmetric key the tx is encrypted with locally. The goal was ultimately to have a field in the tx where client also encrypts the tx key using its long term encryption key, so that it does not need to keep state.

When using HFC to build a solution with Node, is the expected development environment to have the chaincode be included in the overall Node project?  Think of it from the perspective of managing the project in GitHub.  Or, is the expected environment to have 2 separate GitHub projects: one for the Node code and a second for the chaincode?  I ask because it looks tricky how HFC exposes a deploy() interface that takes a chaincodePath which gets (hardcoded) appended to the end of $GOPATH/src/.

<@U2RCN8W95> yes as of hfc 0.6.x chaincode deploy only supports deploying chaincode from a local folder, the chaincode is expected to be at $GOPATH/src in its fully qualified package path, in addition a “vendor” folder must also exist at that folder (peer to the chaincode go file) and contains the fabric source tree

<@U13TWBRBL> Thanks.  That implies to me that $GOPATH is an env variable that should change every time you’re working on a different project, whereas I originally thought that there should be a single/common $GOPATH in a dev env on top of which many projects can be cloned.
<@U2SN3M334|jamesjong> has joined the channel
you can set it up so that all GO projects live under the same $GOPATH
<@U2RCN8W95> say you have projectA and projectB both are golang projects
I’ve got something like that set up now.

$GOPATH/src/
    |__ <http://github.com/mypackage|github.com/mypackage>
                    |__ projectA
                    |__ projectB
assuming both project are in package “<http://github.com/mypackage|github.com/mypackage>"
and “projectA” and “projectB” are your repo roots

But … in the context of creating a Node app that leverages HFC to deploy and invoke a chaincode project … that chaincode needs to be in the same source tree as the Node code.  That implies $GOPATH would need to be specific to my Node project.
ok i see what you are saying
best set up is having the go code (for chaincode) saved separate from application code using node.js

Right - so you could have your Node code in one github repo and your chaincode in another.  You’d clone them down into separate places.  When running locally, your local $GOPATH will point to your generic one, like what you outlined above.  But when deploying to Bluemix, you’d need to ensure a build step is taken to copy the chaincode into your Node project, and then ensure the $GOPATH running on Bluemix would point to the right location.

That’s the tricky part I was getting stuck on … when the Node app is deployed to Bluemix.  In that environment, ONLY your Node app was pushed/deployed.  It must therefore keep the chaincode embedded somewhere, and the hardcoded HFC path to it MUST start with $GOPATH/src.

Context: deploying a chaincode from a Node app using HFC.
Question: Given that Go will do a “go get” to pull down dependencies you have in your chaincode, why is there a need  to manually add in the vendor/hyperledger/… code alongside your chaincode when you deploy your Node app?  Shouldn’t your chaincode’s reference trigger the Go runtime to pull it down for you?
After additional research, the answer appears to potentially be related to limited control over the version that is pulled.  That is, you can only pull the latest

<@U2RCN8W95> this design decision was before I took over the sdk mission, so I can’t say I have all the background that led to that design, but one of the point is that doing “go get” for runtime is dangerous because golang doesn’t have any native versioning support for a published library
you want some level of control over what level of the chaincode shim is being used to execute the chaincode
so a pre-installed package is better
Yep - same conclusion
on the other hand, this area is being improved on for v1.0, such that the fabric shim is now burnt into the base image (”fabric-ccenv”)
that way you still have control over the code level, but don’t need to keep sending it over the wire on deploy

<@U1Y2R5C9L>  <@U1NC8D6V9> : I am assuming this is on the v0.6 branch. Your transaction times out in the case of an error. Rejection event support was developed in parallel with the rest of the events support and has not been fully integrated with transactional events. Loss of events is always going to be an issue so recovery from loss needs to be considered. Having said that, we are planning on looking at adding rejection event support to transactional events in v1.0.

Hi all, is it possible to set user cert attributes after registration is done (through HFC or I suppose chaincode)?  Or is that a registration-time-only facility?
Thanks <@U0KQ9QKH6>

<@U2X9KDDL7> in v0.6 user enrollment cert is only set during memberservice -> enroll(). technically it’s also set when deserializing the member object from FileKeyValStore but that’s all internal and the content came from enroll in the first place. in short, setting ecert is not a public method. what’s your scenario for needing to do this? note that in v1.0 we are making it possible to do this without the memberservice (aka COP), such that you can do something like this:

```
var enrollment = new Enrollment(privateKey, cert);
var user = new Member(name, chain);
user.setEnrollment(enrollment);
user.saveState();
```
this is useful if the app is using an external PKI to generate key pairs and obtain signed certificates

<@U13TWBRBL> I'm exploring if the CA is a reasonable place to manage less-than-permanent attributes, such as issuing/revoking licenses to users to do something which will expire once a particular condition has been reached (preferably in chaincode, but in node.js code as well).  In other words, to see if user cert attributes are mutable with respect to chaincode/app code or not.

text: <@U0N4D2T61> I see, so errorhandling is not implemented yet in the node SDK. <@U0PB67X4K> you were mentioning me yesterday that I can use the hfc to listen for block events, how do I go about that to handle chaincode errors?

<@U0N4D2T61> Sorry my bad, I'll get myself some coffee :slightly_smiling_face:

<@U3AFRMY68> you can hook up nodeSDK (v0.6) to chaincode events like this:

```
var regid = eh.registerChaincodeEvent(testChaincodeID, "evtsender", function(event) {
        console.log(util.format("Custom event received, payload: %j\n", event.payload.toString()));
        eh.unregisterChaincodeEvent(regid);
    });
```
where `eh` is the event hub object you can obtain from the chain object: `var eh = chain.getEventHub();`

you can see a more complete example here written by <@U13Q594J2>:
<https://github.com/ratnakar-asara/NodeSdkSample/blob/master/events/event-sample.js>

<@U3H68QR7X> the “registerAndEnroll()” function is an asynchronous call, so you don’t get the resulting user returned from the function call. instead you pass in a call back function that gets called by registerAndEnroll() with “err, user” parameters. so you’ll handle the resulting user object in the callback function

<@U1RLZ5729> this is your key message:   Error building images: Tag latest not found in repository <http://docker.io/hyperledger/fabric-baseimage|docker.io/hyperledger/fabric-baseimage>

The only reason I can think of for this working with REST API but not with NodeSDK is if you were running in DEV (a.k.a. chaincodedev) mode with the REST API.    

You have to had at some point in your workflow tagged an image as *hyperledger/fabric-baseimage:latest*  and it looks like you didn't perform this step.

For instance if you look in the public Docker hub repo for hyperledger/fabric-baseimage you will not see any *latest* tag.   

Typical workflows I've seen have either:
1) pull down the appropriate tagged fabric-baseimage and tag it as latest, e.g.  *docker tag hyperledger/fabric-baseimage:x86_64-0.2.2 hyperledger/fabric-baseimage:latest*

or

2)  tag a fabric-peer image as fabric-baseimage:latest  (which may not be as 'elegant' but it usually works)  e.g.   *docker tag hyperledger/fabric-peer:latest hyperledger/fabric-baseimage:latest*

Which way would work best for you may depend on how you got your images and what version you're using.

text: <@U2W7U5UA3>: try node v6.x
I seem to recall problems with hfc and node 7.x
At least as a datapoint
There is an issue with GRPC npm module which hfc depends on while using Node 7.x.
in hfc package.json, grpc module is fix referenced to 1.0.0. this issue is resolved in grpc 1.0.1. So, in hfc package.json, this should be updated to 1.0.1

<@U0KM61BCP> <@U0PB67X4K> <@U11MANG9G> I’m trying to get v1.0 node.js SDK published to npm in the next day or two. we need to settle on the name
<@U11MANG9G|jonathanlevi> has joined the channel
i know `fabric-client` and `fabric-ca-client` were mentioned, I think there are problems with these names though because they are not specific enough
`fabric` needs to be qualified with `hyperledger` since npm is a world-wide registry
it’d be more accurate if it’s called `hyperledger-fabric-client` but then that’d be too long, and it’s actually what `hfc` stands for
I’m proposing that we keep `hfc` and add `hfc-ca`
for existing users of hfc v0.6, npm defaults to not update to the next major version automatically (writing `^0.6.2` version range in package.json by default)
so we can publish first as `1.0.0-alpha`
and existing 0.6 users won’t be affected
what do you guys think?
do others in the community have an opinion?
1. I think we may end up publishing a few versions before the final “one” (as in v1, no pun intended)
2. I don’t have a strong opinion regarding `hfc-ca` vs `fabric-ca-client`, but I would like to hear back from <@U0PB67X4K> and <@U0KM61BCP> as well.
Re: 2, I can put it in a JIRA ticket and ask people’s view - I honestly don’t mind, as long as we don’t end up doing the work x3 times.
Re: 1. maybe something with versioning, like rc1… ? (release candidate 1, r. c. 2, …?)
<@U13TWBRBL>: good news on the npm front.  We will need to be sensitive to the version numbers we put out there, FYI
"1.0" has implications with implied exiting from incubation
Something with a suffix ("-preview", etc may be sufficient, as would something less than 1.0
That is my understanding at least.  <@U0KM61BCP> can guide
I am happy to report I did figure out how to get a non-npm release of the SDK consumed by Clojure script
I was struggling with that before

personally, I have always and still do hate the name `hfc` .  I don't think you actually have to preface the package name with `hyperledger` - that can be part of the description / etc which will be indexed for searching npm does not seem like it needs to be in the name of the package itself.   I don't think that the `fabric-` names are awesome, but they seem more clear to me so my vote would still be for `fabric-client` and `fabric-ca-client`  :wink:
<@U0P2GSA8Z|arnaud> has joined the channel
ok, thanks <@U0PB67X4K> for voicing a strong preference, so i’m fine with that, and let’s settle on these names for the npm publish: `fabric-client` and `fabric-ca-client`
<@U0UHG4VP1|ry> has joined the channel
<@U13TWBRBL> - (un)fortunately all my opinions are strong
yes fortunately in this case :wink:
also, now that we are using a different package name, we can start with a lower version than 1.0.x. how about 0.1.0
